ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa Galizia
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa Galizia
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa Galizia
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa Galizia
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Both TAs were very responsive and easy to reach.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar, Marissa
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I worked with both Tamar and Marissa about the same.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar and Marissa.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I interacted with Marissa and Tamar

Instructor: Tamar Makov  I loved both Tamar and Marissa. They we really helpful and very accessible. I think there was a bit of a discrepancy in grading styles though - one seemed a lot tougher than the other, and as a result I felt that my assignments did not receive consistent scores.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Both Tamar and Marissa
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I interacted mostly with Tamar Makov
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa Galizia
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I didn't really interact with the TAs that often except occasionally to clarify assignments. This was done through email.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Responsible Helpful
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Equally with both Tamar and Marissa
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Tamar Makov  Her comments on homework assignments were extremely nit-picky and not helpful, especially given the page limitations of the assignments. If we were to have answered all of her comments, the assignment would have been twice as long. Her presentations in class were hurried, cursory, and were presented in a way that implied she thought we were clueless and ignorant. She asked questions of us as if we were children. It turned me off.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  I'm not sure what value either TF or TA added to this class in general. The greatest contribution was a discussion of NPV and that is something we learn in basic economics. Maybe focus the course more around their own areas of expertise (Tamar could have done a great lesson on the work she did in Israel).

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar is very knowledgeable about this topic area, however I do not believe she was a particularly fair grader. Her criticisms of our group work were unnecessarily nit-picky and when the professor or other TF looked at the same assignment, said that they would have graded it very differently.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  She was very attentive, approachable, and always gave feedback in short time.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  I thought Tamar was very knowledgable, friendly, and approachable! She had great English and command of the subject. I think her presentation skills could have used some improvement (specifically her voice inflection; her voice goes up at the end of sentences and I found this distracting), though overall I enjoyed the lectures that she led. Sometimes her suggestions differed from Marian's when writing the final report, which was a little confusing.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  very helpful and organized, always accessible if we had questions about the assignments and we received a quick response
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Clearly explained and justified points of view. Used thought experiments to encourage class engagement which I believe were effective.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  I often felt that when it came to grading, the TAs were looking for ways to take off points and point out what was wrong, rather than constructively point out what was done right and where there was room for improvement. Based on discussions with other students in the class, it didn't seem like many people understood why certain groups received much better/worse grades than others. This theme seemed to develop over the course of the semester to the point that the classroom did not have a positive atmosphere by the end of the semester.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  They were all very available and excellent.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I did not interact enough with the teacher assistant to be able to assess her strengths and weaknesses
Instructor: Tamar Makov  It was good to see the TAs very engaged with the class topic. I enjoyed Tamar's presentations.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Strengths: Good Researcher Weakness: Needs to handle more politely

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Grading was far too slow to help us improve our work for the course. Faster feedback would allow us to change and grow over the course of the term. Instead the quality of our work stayed relatively unchanged since we didn't receive feedback until well after we were responsible for turning in several other assignments.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Marissa was incredibly accessable and gave insightful comments regarding questions on assignments.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  It would be helpful to receive an updated schedule of due dates, should they change over the course of the semester. Also, I liked looking through the comments on each of my papers, but it would also be helpful to have a rubric for each project before submitting the project.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  The grading in this course seemed arbitrary, and it often appeared the TA's and Chertow were not on the same page. The course seemed as though it was being planned week by week which limited the TA's ability to be helpful. They simply seemed unprepared for student questions because they weren't clear on what was expected either.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The field trip was rescheduled to the first day of Thanksgiving break many weeks into the semester and then said to be "mandatory" when students had already booked their tickets home. Not acceptable. I went on the alternative field trip to the lumber yard. A neat place to visit but was just tagging along to another class's field trip and had nothing to do with our own course. Overall a waste of time.

Needs more in-depth discussion of strategy from a business perspective. Should be co-taught with someone from SOM, where FES can deal with the environmental management, and SOM can deal with the environmental strategy.
None

The class overs a great overview about all topics linked with environment and business strategy and management. Also, we always had great speakers coming in, which allowed us to not only have the theoretical approach but also learn from the experience and insights of the speakers. It was a great combination!

I believe more class participation would be beneficial. The class time focused on introducing topics. I believe this could be better communicated through online videos (30 min). A flipped classroom style would allow more class engagement and discussion in a business school case study format.
This was an excellent class, I learnt from lectures, guest speakers, TAs, and field trip.
With regards to question 15, the course brought together case studies from different regions of the world. I found that interesting because it contextualised many concepts
I really enjoyed this class.

It can be useful to just choose between this course and industrial ecology. They are similar, this one is just more business planning and business concepts relative to the more operations-focused industrial ecology course. They are both useful and can complement each other nicely but the level of overlap can make it seem like you are wasting some of your time.
I enjoyed learning about CEMS topics through my classmates' experiences, as well as through the reading, assignments, and lectures.

Question 2: I enjoyed most of the readings for the class and many of the lectures. The readings weren't too technical and were short enough to be internalized and deeply thought upon for class discussion. However, the assignments were mostly unhelpful in my opinion. I would encourage making assignments like the Unilever case study individual assignments and reading responses instead of group work. Too much of the group work lacked a clear purpose. To make it more productive, there should be more group feedback forms to evaluate each other and more focus on how to work successfully in groups. The group work was mostly just done with friends as quickly as possible instead of building any team skills. Clearer explanations of why an assignment is important and worthwhile would go a long way towards improving the class. Questions 8-10: I understand that the field trip was being planned into the semester and require collaboration from outside companies, so planning is not always smooth. However, I was deeply disappointed that the date of the field trip listed on the syllabus wasn't firm. It took more than halfway into the semester for the field trips to be given a firm date, and yet there was a grade penalty for not going. The field trips weren't during normal class time, so students with regular Friday commitments were put in a position to either renege on those commitments or face a penalty. If the date on the syllabus was final or at least solidified early in the semester, plans could have been made to clear time for an out of class time trip. This issue gets to my main concern about the course. I felt that the plan for the class was constantly changing. Lecture topics changing isn't a problem, but the constant changes to HW assignments that require group work and considerable time to complete was not conducive to learning or helping students be successful.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course is well designed, balancing workload between readings, assignments and final project. Invited guest speakers and the field trip further contributed to a interesting, variegated and multifaceted course.
Fieldtrip, case studies and guest lectures
The final project which gave us a lot of room to explore an area of interest in ways that we could not within the course itself.
It gives a fantastic framework of corporate sustainable management.
The course is very comprehensive, especially the problem sets give me a suitable practical training.
Reading responses - I loved their format and the participation they garnered in class. I especially liked when controversial responses were posted.
A general overview of the different practices in the corporate environmental management field

- speakers - very diverse and great overview on all the important topics related to business and the environment - the assignments are very diverse and engaging and offer students to explore the topic treated in class in a more profound way.
The assignments and additional reading.
The variety of guest speakers brought into the classroom was very useful.
Professor Chertow is an excellent professor. The term project was also great. The term project I did with my classmates ended up making this class probably my favorite this semester.
The lectures, along with the case studies

I really liked that we were only required to do 5 of the 7 assignments over the semester and that there was variability in the type and structure of the assignments This allowed me to balance my schedule and get my work done when it was easiest for me, and to miss an assignment without stressing. I really appreciated that.
The case studies on different subjects
Some interesting cases, and lots of flexibility in the final project. Ample opportunities to practice presenting. Some speakers were great.
The topics covered.
instructor is very friendly and upbeat! the reading materials are good.
Comprehensive and applicable course combing with any practice business cases
Clarity of managment concepts and their relation to environment management.
Field trips and final projects were interesting and allowed for more hands-on learning.
Final Project was the most valuable aspect of this course. Appreciated that ample time to flesh out the project and presentation.
The assignments were challenging and rubric-less, so it was a challenge to produce "good" work.

I really like Professor Chertow. I thought she was a good facilitator of class discussion. Her level of expertise is evident and she brought in excellent guest speakers. I would encourage her to reform her lecture style by using few slides and tighten up each lecture. A better identification of the most important concepts for each lecture with supporting examples from the real world would add clarity. Lastly, I would like to see each lecture mention important skills and further reading related to the topic that students could pursue if they hoped to work in that particular industry after graduation.
The group project in which you could apply the knowledge and skills gained in class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The assignment of groups for the midterm and final project could be improved. I was frustrated with the dynamics of my group (resulting in a much more last-minute approach than I am comfortable with) and there was no opportunity to change.
As to my opinion, there is no need for improvement.

The final project is a disaster. Probably 75% of the time has been figuring out what Marion wants us to actually do, rather than doing a project. She needs to be more organized and more exact with the assignment so we don't waste so much time. Guest speakers were kind of a rag-tag bunch of ho-hum presenters.
Time management in lectures

There needs to be a direct push to making this class more relevant to post-grad school. Specifically, the vast majority of this class focused on the environmental sustainability movements of massive multi-national firms with billion dollar balance sheets. How does that help me in my career as a 27-28 year old coming out of school?
It would be great to have more time for each topic.

The change of the "mandatory" field trip date was a bit of a hassle... I think planning the field trip first for Halloween day, and then moving it to the Friday before Thanksgiving break was a little short-sited, though I am glad that I went on the trip and appreciated the speed and organization of the trip. Perhaps offering two trips (the one that required travel, but would have been more insightful would have been a great option for students), but making one mandatory would have provided more flexibility. I think having more reading responses would have contributed to great learning for me in the class. It was too easy to not do the readings when competing with other class assignments. I also did not like the process of trying to get into the class. It was left until the very last minute and was very stressful.
The class discussions and the material in class can be a build on the readings instead of a general review. Students were already supposed to do the readings in advance.
evt. a organizing a second fieldtrip

The delivery of information in class time by engaging in more case study discussion. Rather than just introducing topics I suggest learning how to implement environmental strategies into corporate scenarios would be considerably more valuable to future practitioners (i.e. students).

Although it was great to be presented with a broad array of CEMS techniques and systems, I don't feel like there was sufficient in-depth analysis done during lecture. The lectures often felt like a race to get through the powerpoint by the end of the class, rather than a lecture that was supplemented by the powerpoint slides. Additionally, the slides were skimmed through very quickly and were much too detailed to adequately read/comprehend what they were saying. Discussions sometimes felt forced, and were not reinforced with commentary by the instructor. There were cases when students asked Dr. Chertow a question during a discussion, but she would hand it off to another student to add a comment, taking the conversation in an entirely different direction. On a separate note, a ten minute presentation to summarize the final project is a very awkward period of time.
Ideally, grading of assignments would be done more quickly.
So far I can't see any

I thought the field trip was unnecessary. It was interesting, but mostly just filler. I didn't think it was necessary, given that it was out of class time and required many people to make special arrangements.

Needs to be brought up to speed. Many, many readings were 15+ years old in a subject that evolves very quickly. Dialogue in classroom was superficial at best - there were students in the room with years of recent experience with environmental management in business from the corporate, government, and NGO side - many of whom never had a chance to be brought into the conversation.
More in-depth assignments on business models would be great.

need better content management in slides and teaching...just going through examples and concepts without clear emphasize on overarching point or concept is not easy to remember in the end. some of the comments from students are outright wrong/controversial and should be clarified or discussed in forum. just gong through the motion of stating own opinion is not helpful. maybe instructor should tell students to be clearer and objectively agree/disagree with other student's comments. the lecture slides need to uploaded at least 1 day in advance so that students can read up and focus more on discussion
It's fine
Making sure it overlaps less with the industrial ecology course.
Class sessions sometimes seemed disorganized.
The slides are helpful, but Marian covers so many topics in a day, and it can be difficult to keep up.

The assignments. I felt that too much was busy work and there was no clear grading rubric. I don't mind getting 7.5 out of 10, but it wasn't clear why points were weighted in the manner they were. In the future, the assignments need much more refining before being given to students. Lastly, I didn't feel the TA's were consistent graders. I didn't find Marissa's comments or grading helpful, and would like to see Chertow take more of the commenting over to ensure high quality.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no lab section
Very relevant lecture choice for the course and always on the edge of the current and newest discussions in that field. There were a lot of great links to conferences organized by CBEY, too.
No lab section, but the relationship between the course lecture and the case studies were really helpful.
Yes the discussions were effective and relevant in most cases.
We don't have much discussion session.
Yes. It was effective. Examples discussed from across the world.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm interested in developing a business strategy focused on long term growth and viability. This course was designed to provide insight into how environmental sustainability and the concept of a 'bottom line' can fit hand in hand.
It fits entirely, since my goal is to focus on industrial ecology, and the subject of this course deals directly with that.

Since I have little background knowledge regarding management before, this course equips me with a overall and integrated insight of environmental corporate management field. It will helpful because entering a private sector's environmental department is one of my career goals.

This class is great for students that want to graduate and become the CSO for an organization, reduce their environmental impact, etc. I don't see that as my long-term goal, but I still enjoyed the class.
It is a general foundation for people interested in business and sustainability.

Focusing on business and the environment the course offered me a first and broad overview of different topics for future career paths and academic interests. It allows discussion about the most current topics in the field of business and the environment. The assignments allow to dive deeper in the theory itself using also practical approaches (Pitch presentation to the class, etc.).

This course was core to my business & the environment focus at Yale. However, there is considerable overlap of this course with other courses. Other similar courses include 'Metrics, tools and indicators in corporate responsibility' by Todd Cort; and 'Principles of Sustainability in Business' by Todd Cort. I suggest faculty discuss overlap to better frame courses and increase attendance.
I want to work in Environmental Consulting, so this course fits perfectly into my career plans.

I'm interested in food. I think that more students with a food interest should take this course, given the global and largely commodified nature of the food system. I think identifying this class as a natural compliment to a food curriculum makes a lot of sense.
Been shifting my focus towards corporate sustainability policies and practices of commodities and extractive companies, so this course formed the conceptual basis for other studies I did.
This was a key course to my overall program because not only it is an F&ES course but also relevant to my carrier as lawyer interested in business and environment
This is a great course for students interested in the intersection of business and the environment and the evolution of business models.
Providing my knowledge outside my program, but the environmental knowledge help me in working for NGOs
I had a base of management concepts. This course was required for me relate them to environment related aspects.
I am interested in sustainable business and industrial ecology and want to work in corporate sustainability.
This course gave me an introduction into CEMS and I'm excited to pursue further work in this field.
I'm business and the environment, so this course is a necessity. Good focus on how making a profit can go hand in hand with environmental management.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this class because I wanted to foster my understanding of how to link environmental consideration with business thinking. In this regard, the tools and strategies I was exposed to throughout the entire semester were relevant and helpful.
Easy elective
I had heard good things about Marian.
Because of the professor and the contents.
It seemed the most interested as compared to the other courses I was considering... and ultimately, I think it was. However, honestly, it does not necessarily fit in with my long-term career plans.
Because I wish to work as a sustainability manager and implement different techniques businesses can adopt to become more sustainable.
Because of my interest in business and the environment. To get knowledge about the key areas of interest to me.

I took this course after dropping another course, partially because I am interested in business and sustainability. I felt it might also be relevant to have at least one management course under my belt before applying to business schools.
I wanted to learn more about Corporate strategies
Because of question 20
I took this course because I seek to work on issues at the intersection between business and the environment in my country
Hoping to gain some insight into the corporate side of environmental policy.
I am interested in innovative business models.
I would like to know more about environment and how exactly society works with it from business side
I had a base of management concepts. This course was required for me relate them to environment related aspects.
I hoped to learn more about bringing sustainable practices to businesses and what you need to do to be successful doing so.
I took this course because I wanted insight into corporate environmental management. I think it met my expectations. The final project was by far the most useful aspect, classes less so.
It blends business and sustainability thinking.
For gaining more knowledge on the business side of sustainability.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: This class came across as a very broad overview. I wish that we had gone into some topics in greater depth, perhaps with a more substantial class discussion component.
Yes. My takeaways are even greater than I thought they would be.
No.
No. Too basic. Too much of a focus on management, without context of strategy.

No, too much theoretical and not enough hands on. I'm not going to be the CSO of Coca Cola anytime soon so don't think their struggles are anything like what I will see in real life for the next 15-20 years.
YES!!!
Yes, they match at a surprising level.
Yes.
Yes, although I expected more rigorous class material.
yes, very much. Some topics were treated more superficially. However, the literature provided and discussion with classmates allowed to dive in deeper if there was a key area of interest.
Yes.
Overall, I was disappointed in the course.
My expectations were exceeded. I learned a lot more than I had anticipated, not only through lectures and assignments but also through group projects.
Yes, the knowledge and skills gained from that class met my expectations
Mostly
Yes
Yes, actually the knowledge acquired exceeded my expectations. I did not expect the course to include case studies from Africa for instance
No.
Yes, it did.
not really as i expected more developed case studies into strategies employed by copmpenies
Yes
Yes it did.
I learned some new things but feel like I could have learned more in the time we had.
Yes, absolutely. Interesting to gain exposure to the different vocabulary.
yes
Unfortunately, no. I would say I was given a cursory overview of some basic business theory, but little was done to support development of tangible skills.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: For the group projects where I could choose my group, I had a fantastic experience. For the midterm and final project, I found the experience frustrating and disappointing.

Throughout the semester, I worked with different groups on the assignments and the final project. It certainly was both academically and personally enriching as I was able to work with many of my fellow students, all having different backgrounds and contributing different point of views and expertise to group discussions. Although coordinating a team of 4-5 students can be a challenging task, it was definitely worth to put effort in it.
Learned effectively from the knowledge of others
Advantages: Got to learn from different people in another school. Disadvantages: Coordinating was really difficult.

There is not enough accountability. Two of the four members of my group were either incompetent, didn't care, or were out of the country. However, one member of my group was great so helped me explore my own interests and turn in a strong paper.

I didn't really like the topic I was assigned, but that was fine... we made the most of it. I had difficulty working with ESL students (which was half of my group); I felt like more of a burden on editing fell towards me and they even acknowledged that. Perhaps splitting up the ESL students more would have alleviated that.

Disadvantages of the group work are the fact that we had to work on a certain topic form a limited pool of choice and there was not a smooth cohesion between group members. In another situation, I wish I would have had the opportunity to work in a smaller group ( less than 4 people) on another chosen topic of my interest.

The group work was a great experience and made the class richer. I learned to work in groups with different nationalities. I appreciated also that for every assignments the groups changed so we got to know the classmates very well.
Advantage: working with many personalities. Disadvantage: not being forced to work through problems with personalities because you choose a different group every week.

For most of the assignments, working in a group made completing the assignments much less of a burden. However, for the final project and even one of the smaller homework papers, working in a group with students who didn't speak English as their first language resulted in much more work for myself and the other English speakers. We often would have to nearly re write sections written by these students, which was certainly challenging.
Generally my teammates in most assignments were great collaborators. That was not always the case.
Working in group was very useful, as a way to enhance constructive discussion. I also practice my leadership, by learning to take the lead.

Group projects depend on the group. I enjoyed most of my groups, especially my final project group. Other group assignments were miserable. I think having a balance of group or non-group assignments was valuable because it meant that we didn't ALWAYS have to work in groups.
Advantages were to share knowledge and opinions, and to share the workload. Disadvantages were the sometimes disproportionate load that group members took on.

The advantages or working in a group is that you get to discuss with your peers but I have to say there is lot of waste of time with discussions. Some times the group members have different understanding of the issues at hand and this can delay the work or impact negatively on the outcome.

Advantages include project design - very flexible, well timed, great opportunity to work on something interesting. Disadvantage was two team members were complete free riders - the worst I've encountered in 3 semesters at Yale.
The group work was very helpful because it was a great way to understand concepts collaboratively.
the assignments are great for group work although time to present in front of class wasn't enough for well developed presentation.

It's great for group work to have people's different ideas combined, making the project more comprehensive. However, it's always a problem in negotiating with time schedule and things like that that impedes efficiency

Advantage - Learning Group Dynamics Disadvantage - One gets confused on realizing that the individual response to a section in a group assignment gets full marks (5/5), but the grading of the responses of other group members could be as low as 1/5 adversely affecting one's total score / grade

The case assignments are too small to be worked on in groups and have a meaningful impact on your learning. We should each have to do our own complete case responses so we get everything we need to out of them. If you split up the work it takes too little time and you only get a snapshot of what you might have gotten working on it alone (like you would at SOM).
Great to have more minds sleuthing through a project. Lack of some group members participation was tough. Would still prefer group over non group for the scale of the project.
Some groups were highly productive/effective, and others were less so. If we had more time to work on assignments together, our group dynamic was better overall.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: My advice is quite simple: There could be no more rewarding course than this one if you are interested in both industrial ecology and business strategies. TAKE THIS CLASS!
An excellent introduction to a wide range of business considerations
Consider SOM strategy courses.
Make sure that you develop a final project that is truly of your own academic and professional interest because that is the avenue through which you will gain the most for the semester.
Be prepared to a lot of work... But don't worry, it's totally worth it!
1) make sure you realize that this class is really for people who want to work within or consult for a business that is looking towards reducing their environmental footprint
This is a good foundation course for anyone interested in corporate sustainability. Goes into depth in different model and techniques that help businesses be more sustainable.
Definitely read the lectures provided and although the class demands a lot of work, it is worth it.
This course should be titled 'An Overview of Corporate Sustainability with a focus on Environmental Management'

Be very strategic in choosing assignments and work partners. Make sure to set group expectations early and stay on top of the final project because it is not referenced often in class and there is not much guidance given.
I recommend this class. The advice is that it is a very fast pace class, with a load of reading higher than average. so be ready to pace yourself.
Do the readings ahead and attend the course.
Think about possible final projects early enough.
Read the required readings for each lecture, that would be helpful
Be careful in group selection. Work as if you are individually working on the assignment.

Weigh up whether you really want/need to take this course compared with the Industrial Ecology course. This one is probably a little less intense and heavy on details than that one so it might give you a good idea whether or not you are interested in learning more about I.E.
Keep up with the readings as best you can, and ask for grading rubrics before handing in each assignment.
Good overview of many approaches to business sustainability and environmental management/strategy. Would definitely recommend this course.
